BUS LANES IN CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT
(Request for abolition)


    1. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Communications if he will consider abolishing the existing "Yellow Bus :Lanes" within the Central Business District as well as along all the City's main roads when the Park and Ride Scheme is introduced, as the existence of the bus lanes tends to obstruct shoppers boarding and alighting from cars or taxis in front of shops.

Column: 362



    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the purpose of Reserved Bus Lanes during traffic peak hours in the Central Business District is to give priority to public bus transport. Observations made by officers of the Registry of Vehicles and the Road Transport Working Group, since its introduction in February 1974, have shown that this measure has been successful. The Reserved Bus Lane scheme will therefore be maintained. Another traffic management scheme, the Park and Ride Scheme, to be introduced in May this year, will further facilitate traffic flow.

    Shoppers who experience some inconvenience in boarding and alighting from cars and taxis in front of shops because of the bus lanes could avoid inconvenience by doing their shopping outside the peak periods when bus lanes are not operative.

USE OF COMMUNITY CENTRE'S GROUNDS


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Culture the reasons why the People's Association cannot allow the use of a Community Centre's playground for the holding of a dinner party by a civic organisation to commemorate the birthday of a certain Chinese deity.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, community centres are meant to serve the interests of the community as a whole and not religious or sectional interests. The People's Association, therefore, does not as a general policy grant permission to a civic organisation to stage any functions or activities of a purely religious nature inside community centre's grounds.

ENGLISH TEACHERS IN PRIMARY SCHOOLS
(Particulars)


    3. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Education, in respect of primary schools, (a) the number, as on

Column: 363

1st March, 1975, of (i) vacancies for qualified English teachers in the English schools; and (ii) relief teachers employed to fill those vacancies; (b) the number, as on 1st March, 1975, of (i) vacancies for trained English teachers in the Chinese, Malay and Tamil schools; (ii) relief and untrained teachers filling those vacancies; and (iii) schools which did not have relief teachers; and (c) the total number of English teachers who resigned between 1st January, 1973 and 28th February, 1975.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Ahmad Mattar) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir:

    (a) (i) As at 1st March, 1975, there were 125 vacancies for English-medium teachers in English primary schools.

    (a) (ii) All the 125 vacancies were filled by relief teachers. In addition, another 84 relief teachers were employed to fill casual vacancies arising from their holders being away on various forms of leave; e.g, maternity leave, study leave, etc.

    (b) (i) There were 33 vacancies for English-medium primary school teachers in the Chinese stream, nine vacancies in the Malay stream, and one in the Tamil stream.

    (b) (ii) All the vacancies were filled by relief teachers.

    (b) (iii) The primary schools that did not have relief teachers were as follows:- 

   (1)  English schools  :   35

   (2)  Chinese schools  :  109

   (3)  Malay schools    :   21

   (4)  Tamil schools    :    6
All these schools had full staff complements. There are a total of 369 primary schools in Singapore.

    (c) Out of a total of 6,006 English-medium primary school teachers, 301resigned from the service over the two-year period between 1st January, 1973,and 28th February, 1975.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [3rd March, 1975], `That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1975 to 31st March, 1976.".-[Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

2.43 p.m.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to congratulate the Minister for his Budget statement. It was short; I dare not say it was short and sweet. It was a brief, businesslike presentation, reviewing economic policy against the scenario of the economic survey of Singapore 1974 and the Memorandum on the Main and Development Estimates, as well as the detailed estimates themselves. Not long before the Budget statement, of course, the President's Speech at the opening of Parliament outlined the general policy of the Government. All these should make up the total backdrop to the presentation of Members' views today.

    The Government has, of course, to be praised for having guided us through 1974 adroitly, managing a relatively good growth rate, encouraging or contriving diversification in the manufacturing sector in terms of manufacturing activities, and in the trade sector, in terms of markets. In respect of trade, while vigorous marketing is of course important, emphasis must be laid on

Column: 367

the quality of goods supplied, but very important also, on the integrity of our traders.

    While there is no doubt that the great majority of our traders are reliable, there have been one or two black sheep. For instance, a very bad example has been set by one or two exporters of sawn timber who have indulged in such malpractices as to bring upon themselves, and unfortunately on others too, the distrust of buyers. It is significant also that ungraded timber is shipped mostly to west Asian countries and this is particularly one area in which, as the Finance Minister's Budget statement states, we are seeking new markets. Our merchants know that the best advertisement is the quality of their goods and service. We should make it very clear that we will not allow a few to spoil the good name of the majority.

    Quite early in his Budget speech, the Minister referred to the importance of tourism in the services sector of our economy. Even you, Mr Speaker, in those days, when as a Backbencher you could speak, you did touch on the importance of protecting our tourists from dishonest dealing. I think this matter has been taken care of, and is continually being looked after. But more recently on another aspect the Finance Minister remarked publicly that there is no reason why the tourist industry should help to import the more undesirable manifestations of Western life-styles.

    There is also every reason indeed, Mr Speaker, why the tourist industry should help in the promotion of our cultural development through greater encouragement of the arts, and propagation of life-styles that will result in tourists having a good opinion of us not only for our material achievements, but also for our pleasing and respectable cultural attainments. I think this is a more correct picture for them to take away.

    With regard to expansion of tourism, I myself do not have it very clear in

Column: 368

my mind as to whether it is owing to the efforts of the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board that we are getting more tourists, or whether people would come in any case on the basis of promotion by our national airlines, our missions abroad and by the natural advantages of Singapore's convenient location, as well as by other features, as for example the fact that Singapore is a clean city with green and pleasant surroundings, and has also a reputation for being well-run. What stands out as a particular achievement of the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board is the discovery of a rather controversial location for Sir Stamford Raffles' landing. Other contributions to tradition and cultural development do not seem to prevail very much. It is interesting to note that more tourists from ASEAN countries are visiting Singapore. Let us show them that we are conscious of our own history and commendable past and that we appreciate the finer forms of expression.

    To help in this, I would like to bring up the view held by many that some part of the proceeds from the cess levied on tourist establishments he given over for the patronage of artistic and cultural development.

    The Budget statement sounded a note of firm confidence in the face of continued uncertainty in world economic conditions. We show confidence in ourselves and we know that others are confident in us. And this I say to our people: let us not do anything to affect this confidence in any way. The Member for Changi has, during the debate on the President's Address, expressed his concern over the possibility of Communist exploitation of economic uncertainties as well as of come-back attempts by right-wing political opportunists. The Member for Boon Teck has also referred to unwelcome interference by "ugly adventurers" in our internal political affairs.

    Not too long ago we witnessed at the University of Singapore some manifestations of student unrest. In respect of students experiencing an awakening within their souls to the realities of

Column: 369

conditions in the adult world they find themselves in, the members of our society should look upon this with some gratification. We should not feel too perturbed or surprised even over our discovery of evidence of intellectual activity at the University of Singapore. We should be happy that our undergraduates are studiously exercising themselves over moral issues as to the kind of society we should have and the right relations between man and man in our society.

    At the same time we should also remember that the student movement is the easiest thing in the world for those with unwholesome intentions to penetrate silently and surreptitiously. In the spring of 1967, Ramparts magazine published a most significantly revealing report. The report claimed that the (American) National Student Association (NSA), to which was affiliated student unions on more than 300 campuses all over the United States, had been subsidised for 15 years past by the Central Intelligence Agency.

    This support from the CIA had been to counter Soviet influence in the international student movement, which had been evident since as far back as 1946, when Communist delegations gained control of the first World Student Congress, which met in Prague. More recently, there is also a fair amount of evidence of Communist penetrations of the Students for a Democratic Society (SDS). In an odd way our own students show they realise their vulnerability to penetration by constantly expressing their fear of subversion by our Internal Security Department.

    All in all, our students, especially those just entering university, should be warned against being pawns of shadowy individuals lurking in the background. These individuals, while espousing humanistic aims and individual freedom, cynically exploit the difficulties our idealistic youths are facing in their struggle to relate the first flush of new ideas and exciting thoughts to the realities of their social and political environment.

Column: 370



    In the university recent attempts at expressing dissent have followed a well-beaten path, trodden over and over again by student dissenters all over the world. Sing-along sessions, the pretence of humanism hiding the incitement to hate, making a comrade of Christ, and Messiahs out of student officials, the manufacturing of martyrs, the desanctification of authority and the attempt to pour scorn on social institutions, including the judiciary directly, and even Parliament indirectly, attempts at disruption and willingness to drop out: the pattern is very clear. Our young men and women entering into university should be warned against being made use of by those who do not wish us any good.

    Now let me turn to the more pedestrian domain of our school system. Of course, the Minister for Finance has made reference to some sectors of our education system which are directly relevant to manpower training and are in this way immediately related to economic progress. He has thus expressed his concern over the relationship of education to work and certainly this is a right concern. But there are other aspects of the formal educational system not immediately and patently seen as having economic significance which will have in the long run very important effects on our economic and social well-being. This should concern us especially in view of our President's injunction not too long ago that we should be guided by the long-term interests of all our people. I feel certain there are features in our education establishment and implementation of education policy, which may in the long run tend to result in diseconomies than in efficiency and optimum output. I refer to the way measures are introduced and dropped and new measures thought of and introduced in bewildering succession. In November 1974 an official statement on the restructure of the education system averred that our Republic's education system had been in operation for the past 15 years with only minor changes. This statement has resulted in my

Column: 371

wondering whether I have rightly understood the meaning of `major' and `minor'. But even if the changes have not been major and have indeed been minor as alleged, then there have been so many of them introduced, and in a patchwork way, that it was right for the Member for Ulu Pandan to call out for a moratorium on these changes.

    Let us sit down to think carefully of what we want to do and let us do it together, teachers and administrators -not the bureaucrats alone. Let not policy be decided in some obscure bureau and the views of teachers and their unions and other professional bodies be sought merely to ensure smooth implementation of a new system.

    As early as 1968 a point was made in this House in respect of decision-making regarding educational policy. It was said that when plans were made not enough of the opinion of the rank and file of the teachers had been solicited and it was pointed out that without discussion there could not be that full and wholehearted commitment to implementation. I myself appealed in this House seven years ago, that whenever decisions were to be made, whenever plans were to be laid, we needed more than a resigned acquiescence to these decisions and plans. We needed the participation of our teachers in the thinking out of our problems.

    Today, Mr Speaker, Sir, this response of resigned acquiescence to decisions is still there. What other response can there be when decisions are still made and policies thrust on teachers for them to implement and their views are canvassed only in respect of smooth implementation. Where is the optimum productivity possible under these conditions? How is the best economic effort achieved in the education sector?

    There is also another matter which is related to what I would like to think of as the economic disposition of educational resources. Why is it that we try to contrive an input of all sorts of knowledge, possible and impossible, into schooling? The reason for this is that

Column: 372

we visualise the formal school as the only place where learning should occur. That is why we tend to ask: Why has history been dropped? There is not enough second-language time. Why not include consumer education, even family planning education, safety first education perhaps, and other things? If we could only realise clearly that education is for life, then we could take more positive steps to integrate a humane and civic education into the working and adult life of our citizen.

    Presently, in the out-of-school sector, we have done very well indeed in the establishment of institutions devoted to the improvement of work skills. But where education for living is concerned the time that we have at our disposal, if we think only of school, is quite inadequate. We have to think of other structures to bring about with effect and impact what is incorporated in the Chinese saying - Huo tao lao, hsueh tao lao - Live till old, learn till old.

    With that let me turn to the way priorities seem to be ordered in the minds of those who decide on the Budget for items that are not related immediately to economic returns, but which are all the same important and have a long-term effect on the way our people live, learn, train, work and earn, and hence on the way we progress economically and otherwise. Let us take., for instance, the example of neglect of the National Museum. It is depressing to contemplate this aspect and I intend to say a little bit more during Committee of Supply.

    Then there is the National Library. There has been a spate of resignations recently of officers in the library service. Further alarm and despondency has been spread among senior library officers by certain proposals relating to so-called economy and efficiency measures that, if implemented without careful consideration, may well result in hampering the optimum development of our library services.

    Even where the traffic police are concerned, suggestions have been made to them to reduce the strength of the

Column: 373

mobile squad. This has been done apparently in the naive belief that the introduction of the points demerit system, restricted entry into the CBD, and other new traffic regulations, will enable fewer men to do more work. By such crude economies, is it hoped that the traffic police will achieve what, up to the present, has patently not been achieved, namely, adequate volume of enforcement?

    It is quite evident that when our budget authorities (wherever they are) budget for enterprises that are not immediately economically productive, they tend to think of manpower and other operating factors in terms of reducible digits. In the Memorandum to the Estimates, we learn that half the rationale behind latest improvements to the Estimates format is to enable classification of Government expenditure according to the economic impact of an expenditure. My own observation inclines me to believe that, in cases of expenditure where there is not an immediate, patent, quantifiable economic impact, then this is seized upon as justification for automatic pruning.

    There does not seem to be much readiness to think in terms of dimensions of a problem, or the aims of a project - what it is hoped to attain by it. Productivity is demanded in a simple way: greater output with fewer digits. This is like the father in a family economising by giving his children less to eat. Whether they will do more work because they are lean, or much less because they are starving - this may well be a less simple judgment to make.

    When a look is taken at productivity, it may be all too easy to come to facile, unctuous conclusion about the necessity for pruning. One has to guard against this mistake. For example, I had occasion, only a few days ago, to visit Fullerton Building. There I passed a department of the Ministry of Finance. While waiting, I saw a few of the staff of this department, sauntering between desks, lounging, and talking with one another, full of smiles. But I said to

Column: 374

myself: "My, these workers are indeed happy. They must surely be owing this happiness to the efforts of the Management Services Department."

    And now, Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Minister will allow, I would like to comment on the bland way in which the Minister presented his Budget statement. There was no break in this bland quality even when he came to the part where he talked about additional revenue having to come from increased taxes on items, 1 quote, "not basic to life for the average family". This imposition was, I think, greeted with mixed feelings on the part of Singaporeans - a little irritation mixed with a little relief: relief that the imposition had not been heavier because there were rumours that the tax on cars, for example, would be high indeed. And a little irritation because at least one of these items, namely the car, is not considered so much a luxury, under present circumstances, as almost a necessity to large numbers of people, judging by the perennial parking problem even in HDB precincts and other places where the average citizen dwells. The principal way to make people less attached to their cars is to make travelling in public transport so much less deterring than it is today, that people will not mind sacrificing the use of private vehicles.

    There is no doubt that one aim of the imposition of additional road tax is to add to the discouragement of individual car ownership. Most people feel, however, that this measure will not succeed - and the people who feel so are the people who own the cars. I appreciate that it is necessary, in order to make public transport a success, to ensure a high volume of users of public transport, who will later patronise the mass rapid transit system. Thus it is necessary to discourage individual car ownership wherever possible. And I support all encouragement given to the use of public transport. But apart from quasi-punitive measures, it is a positive and radical transformation of the public transport system that will eventually turn people to its use.

Column: 375



    However, we should not forget the revenue-collecting purpose behind the imposition of the additional car tax. A respectable $26 million is anticipated. But the burden will be chiefly borne by those who own small and medium-sized cars. It would be interesting to know how many of these owners also run small and medium-sized businesses. It is hoped that, in such cases, the taxes will not be passed on to the consumer, in another little boost to inflation.

    Especially as the Government has, by its own measures, done its part, otherwise, in arresting the rate of inflation. Comparing 1974 with 1973, the rate of increase in the cost of living has slowed down significantly. However, food contributes nearly 60% to increases in the Consumer Price Index. There is reason, therefore, for us to welcome the coming Government campaign to drive home the message that good food need not necessarily mean the higher priced food. Success in the campaign will not only help the housewife in her domestic bud-getting but will perhaps also contribute towards pegging down general food prices somewhat. I wonder, though, if we should not give thought to the possibility that success in increasing the demand for lower-priced foodstuffs might send the prices of these foodstuffs up a bit.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, on the whole, there is very little doubt that the Government has done well for the citizens who gave it their mandate. And it is geared under present recessionary conditions, to maintain a fair rate of development. The Estimates show nearly a 50% increase, in FY 75 over FY 74, in Government's direct expenditure on development (excluding expenditure on the Armed Forces). Significantly a sum representing about one-tenth the amount of this direct expenditure will be spent on public works, especially roadworks, necessitated by development of housing. Nearly $850 million has gone into loans for housing. There is nearly a 40% increase in the amount of loans to Statutory

Column: 376

Boards and Companies, including over $700 million in the Ministry of Finance's Development Estimates.

    In the private sector, the reason is plain economics for the employer. In fact, an employer may not even wait for the employee to retire but retrench him before he has reached the top of his salary scale. The employer retires an old employee at the top of his salary scale. With the same amount of money he can employ three or four young inexperienced employees at the bottom rung of the salary scale. This is sometimes done without consideration of the value of the skill and experience of the old employee. The reason is simple. The personnel manager of a firm who is in charge of hiring and firing of the staff wants to show his general manager how much money he can save for his company if he retires or retrenches off an old employee and recruits a young employee. As the personnel manager is not in charge of production and is not concerned with production efficiency and schedules which depend so much on skilled and experienced employees, the problem he creates has to be solved by others. The production manager and supervisor, who apparently have not much say in the hiring and firing of employees, are the ones who have to solve the problem. But since they probably depend on the goodwill of the personnel manager for their own job security and promotions, they also prefer to keep their wisdom to themselves.

This is really necessary as a measure of efficiency, and the problems to he dealt with should be dealt with at as low a level as possible. Only when these problems are not capable of solution at these lower levels should they be referred upwards. So the problems such as those of compliance with financial regulations or authority for expenditure and so on are, in fact, devolved upon the clerical service and perhaps the executive service.
